segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hi everyone. This is turning my phone into a scheming device and post solutions. We'd like to
introduce ourselves briefly. I'm Ileana Barrionuevo. I'm a security engineer and security
researcher at UTN. I am from Cordoba, Argentina. And this is Dan Borgogno.
Hi, uh, I'm a security engineer, uh, uh, security, security researcher. There are two tags if
you want to, to follow us. Uh, I work at Latus Seguros. We are trying to protect data and people
through a new type of risk, uh, risk management. Democratizing cyber insurance, saving
companies from bankruptcy after cyber attacks through advanced, uh, risk analysis. Uh,
this is the agenda. Well, we'll talk about why we chose these devices, these solutions. We
talked security concerns that we found and how we hack them by taking different paths such
as network traffic analysis, application analysis, Bluetooth, hardware, and so on. Go ahead.
So, what are, uh, digital wallets and what, what's the impulse and how everything is
connected? Well, digital wallets are a way for you to have your money stored in your, in your
phone. Basically you can receive money, you can transfer money, or you can do operations with
your money. Uh, the problem comes when you have a business, you want to receive payments from
anyone. For example, you're sending things and you are trying to, to get payments from a guy
that doesn't have the same wallet or may have a credit debit card. So these devices basically
what they do is they allow you to interact with the credit card information and to receive the
data that you need to make a payment. And they're connected through Bluetooth. These
solutions are widely available in Argentina so that's why we try to, to analyze them. And as
you can see, they are pretty common. There are a lot of, of devices that are out there. Uh, we
have very different, uh, digital wallets and all these devices have, uh, different providers.
You can see on the bottom that there is a lot of providers, VBoss, MagicBoss, Stripe,
Display, uh, amongst others. So, um, you need to keep in mind that you have the, the, the, the
manufacturer and the digital wallet implementator. And the one thing that you need to keep in
mind as well is that the attacker right now might be the digital wallet owner. So you have
this device, you have this business, you are trying to receive payments. When you are
receiving a payment you need to protect the client data from the guy that's paying and using
his credit card to, to give you money. So right now the attack surface, uh, it's a little
bit bigger and we would choose these devices to, to assess them. Is that in the first case
is that they are sending very critical information over Bluetooth, which is critical
information. So, uh, we might, you, you might know that Bluetooth, uh, 4.0 is very
vulnerable. You can do a shyhack attacks and you can do a lot of stuff with Bluetooth. So our
first question was, uh, how secure is this? It's really secure. You can really see the
critical information from the air or not. This is that difficult. On the other hand, uh, we
saw that, um, differently from the, the components or the, the inputs that have a specific
system embedded in it. When you're trying to use your mobile application with those devices,
you can control the, the data flow. You can control the payment process. And this is
really, uh, it's a big problem because right now you can try amongst other things to make a
reply attack. You can try a different payment. You can show the client, uh, one amount of
money and then charge it for a bigger amount or something like that. So we try to figure
out how vulnerable is that the, the, the critical owner, the, the digital owner can manipulate
the, the payment flow. And the third, third thing is that we have a really wide attack
surface. You can hack data entry. You can hack the hardware. You can hack the firmware. You
can hack the Bluetooth. You can do a shyhack over Bluetooth. You can have manipulation of
the application. You can reverse an SDK that, uh, uh, third parties provide to you to
integrate with your digital wallet. You can manipulate network traffic. There's a lot of
things you need to implement security measures on each one of those steps. So the attack
surface is really big. So as you can see this is a simple graphic, uh, all those are attack
points, right? So you can try to get the critical information for example in each one of
those points. So the other thing that you need to understand is what are the features that
these, those devices provide. Um, these devices, uh, allow you to read EMB which is the, the
chip from the credit card. You can read the MAC stripe information which is the black stripe
in the back of your credit card, your credit card. You can read NFC and receive NFC, NFC
payments. And those devices allow, uh, firmware update over the air. They receive over the air,
uh, key updates because I will explain later how the key system management works. And they
have Bluetooth, uh, low energy and EDR which is the 3.0. And they support pretty much
every, uh, payment standard. And you need to keep in mind that to understand, uh, what we've
done is that these devices encrypt critical information to be sent to the backend and the way
this is done is by a key management system, um, a protocol which is called the UKPT.
Basically what this device, uh, have is a specific key. You have a, uh, um, uh, wallet
provided. You have a master key and for each one of the devices that are going to the market
you will generate a specific key which is called the EPEC. And this key will be embedded in
the firmware and then for each transaction that we'll try to do, you'll try to generate a
new key, a session key, to encrypt this information and when this information gets to the
backend, Cypher with, uh, triple S, the backend system will try to generate the same key
based on the device itself and the transaction that is occurring. So there is no interchange
of a key but this is a Cypher, uh, Cypher channel between the device and the backend. So
after that the best, the transaction when, uh, it's, it's, it's get done. And the other thing
that you didn't understand is that critical information provides a lot of stuff. Amongst
them you can read, uh, Maxstripe. You can, uh, the Maxstripe is, uh, a stan- uh, it's a fixed
data. You can clone it. It's not something that you can change. Um, you have AMB data, NFC
data which is, uh, a specific protocol that allows you to make payments but they have, uh,
another additional Cypher link over it. Uh, I won't get into details but you need to know
that there's a different protocols and stuff that you can get from a critical. So moving on
to network traffic. Well, we started analyzing one of the cases, one of the application
vendors that interacts with this device and well, we intercepted the traffic. We actually
realized that we can read and modify any data traveling on the request and the responses. We
use Frida, Objection, Meet and Proxy, Burp Suite and well, any proxy. And we can control the
whole payment flow and we capture, we can capture the encrypted information that comes from
this device and we can try different use cases such as reusing data, reconstructing
information. Well, we have to break the SSL pinning so we use Frida scripts and running
with Objection and a proxy. And here we have the first abuse case which is data
reconstruction. We have seen that this particular application was managing information. We
have obtained information from the backend that wasn't used at the front end so we have seen
that. That is the encrypted information, the credit card number and the CVV and
expiration et cetera. But the backend returns the same information and non-encrypted. So
there you see the first A numbers of the credit card number and the GNI and the last four
numbers and expiration date. So, well, that data wasn't being used at front end so we
should try to reconstruct the complete credit card number. So how many attempts should I
do? Nearly 9,000, right? But to get these four numbers that we are missing, we should do
only 999 attempts because the credit card number follows a specific structure that can be
validated with that script for example, right? So we should do brute force and then we get
these four missing numbers and then we have the whole picture to make payments, malicious
payments. So even though the credit card data was traveling ciphered when the response for
each one of the payments came through, you can get this data to reconstruct any credit
card information. Um, well, this is a next obvious case which consists of reusing data. To
you KPT states that the key, the transaction key should be used once and then should be
discarded. So, what if we resend a request that has the encrypted information with this
key traveling in the request? What if we resend the request after a valid payment? It should
fail following the standard but here we have the process, we initiate the transaction, the
customer makes a payment on the device, we capture by analyzing the traffic, we capture the
request, the transaction goes well, it's accepted but then when the customer leaves the store,
we start it, we trigger another payment with our cards but then we replace the request with
the credit card information that is encrypted but we have saved it previously. And then we
make another payment. So you should keep in mind that there is a grey area between the
responsibilities of the device provider and the cre- uh, and the digital wallet owner. So
these things comes to get in the grey area that no one wants to take responsibility about,
the things that you should do and you should not do, do with the, the grey data.
And here we are positioned as merchants. We are the attacker merchants. So here's a demo of
the reply attack. So we have 2 phones with 2 different applications and we're trying to make a
payment from, on the first digital wallet, capture the data and then we open a second, uh,
digital wallet with a second device and we'll try to dummy, uh, credit card payment and then
we'll replace this credit card data, dummy data with the previous one and we'll, you will
see that we have a successful transaction. So right now, uh, everything's connected to
Meet and Proxy. Um, I already done a transaction. So the, the payment went through. So,
sorry, this is a first payment. Uh, already connected. I'm getting the traffic from Meet and
Proxy. I just received the encrypted credit card information from the first payment. And
again, don't bother about, uh, getting this data. Uh, it's all fixed so you won't be able to
use this data. But once the, right here I'm, I'm, uh, using a simple identification number
that you need in Argentina to make a payment. And you'll see that the transaction, it's
approved. So the client left the store, goes to their home, pretty happy. He paid 55 pesos.
And I'll turn off the Wi-Fi and leave everything on the side. And I use a different, um,
account in another phone. I'm getting the information, the green information that shouldn't be
used to, to re-send, uh, for another payment. And saving this data, just in a text file. Uh,
that's cipher data. You can see the key SN which is a transaction key, which allows you to
generate on the back end the new key to service data. And right now I'm turning the phone, uh,
Wi-Fi to make another payment. That's a dummy card. This, uh, it's already expired. And I use
it to make another, uh, initial payment. So right now I'm intercepting the traffic. And I
will replace this data. So turn on the device. Make another payment for a bigger amount.
That's about a dollar. And right now you'll see that I'll trigger the, the device. But I
will capture the information on traffic, on network traffic. I will replace the, the
information with the previous one. And I resume the, the traffic. And you'll see that right
now I need to, again, import all the data. This is not valid, so I just can input whatever I
want. And you'll see that the transaction went through. So. There, there are more things.
Wait, wait, wait. So you can see that right here I, we have, uh, the, sorry I was trying to
show you. Oh man. It was the second transaction and the wallet from the customer with a, with a
valid payment. Yeah, you can see right here we have the two payments from the same client.
And the second payment was never, never actually executed. It was, and it was charged. So,
going back to the presentation. Okay, well, let's move on to application analysis. We have
seen network traffic and now we are going to hook the methods from the SDK. It's the, the
SDK, sorry. And we have the SDK and the device interacting with the application. So, we try to
manipulate the objects, the instances related to the encrypted card information coming from
this. So, we are abusing TUKPT implemented here. And remember that we have this case in
which we cannot reuse the key because this was fixed. This was reported and fixed. We
shouldn't use again the same request. But encrypted card information shouldn't be used
again. So, we are the ones interacting with the SDK and the device. So, we can manipulate
and get as many keys and as many encrypted card information as we want. This was
theoretical. We thought about it last year. We tested this year and it worked. So, how it
works. We initiate a transaction. The customer is going to pay, taps the card on this device.
We capture that card, encrypted card information, right? And we try to make the payment
fail. So, in the second attempt from the customer, we are sending to you the previous card
information. And in this second tap, this second attempt from the client, we are capturing
also that information and we are saving it on memory. And then when the customer leaves, we
are going to pay again with this second tap that we captured. And the transaction will be
accepted. This is a little script that we developed to run with objection. We hooked the
method, the serializer that triggers the request that completes the operation, the payment.
And we enumerate all the instances related to the objects, the credit card information that
comes from here. And, well, we can save on an array or send to a server. And in the first
attempt, we are sending data in order to make the payment fail. And, well, that method returns
this first instance. And then we are sending the previous card information that we are
saving in each tap. And, well, we are sending information to a server if we want. And, well,
in order to understand this process, we have two requests. The first one that initiates the
payment. And the second one that completes that operation with an operation ID that is got
from the first request. Now in the demo, we are showing you the requests and responses. But I
wanted to make it clear that we are not manipulating the traffic. We are only manipulating the
instances at run time. We are manipulating and hooking the methods of the SDK. So let's start
the demo. Well, we are starting the application. The customer is going to receive the
payment. The customer is going to pay. We are pairing the device. This is the first tap. We are
capturing the information. But we are sending data in order to make the payment fail. Well, we
are completing the DNI for legal reasons. And then we are triggering the first request, starting
the payment with valid data. But the second one is GME data. Because we want to make the
payment fail. Right? So then there's an error. And we say the customer, hey, let's try it
again. We have captured this valid information from the credit card. And in this second tap, we
are capturing also the credit card information. But we are sending the previous one from the
first tap that we have captured. So completing again. Legal data. And then we are sending
well, starting the payment again. Because this is a valid transaction. We get an operation ID
which is needed to complete the transaction later with this second request. And then we are
sending the previous card information that we have saved. And this wasn't used. Well, we have
triggered now the malicious payment. The customer leaves the store. Really, really happy. Then we
trigger another payment. As an attacker. As a merchant attacker. And we are sending the
payment. We start the operation. We get the operation ID from the first request. And then we are
sending this previous card information from the customer. Which is encrypted. I don't need to
know what the credit card number is. So we completed a payment. So here we have a valid
transaction. And the customer will see a second payment. But just to clarify, we tried to
manipulate the price. But this was validated at backend. So the price was the first one that the
customer paid previously. So that was the demo. And the second one.
And well, just to, in order that you understand how the script is. This is a script running
with Objection. We are capturing the first tap. But we tamper the method. The situation.
And we send the data. Yeah. We are saving card information. We are linking it to a server.
And this is the second tap when the customer tries again. But we are sending the previous one.
Right? The first one. Well, this is the attacker tap. And we are sending the first one.
The second tap from the customer. It's a little, a little strange but we are sending previous
data. And the payment goes well. So, let's move on to Bluetooth. So, Bluetooth analysis. Uh, we
don't open all the devices. There are mainly 4. And all of them share pretty much the same
uh, Bluetooth chip. Which is the iChip YC1021. This, if you go to the data sheet, you'll see
that this device supports Bluetooth 3.0 and 5.0. And you might know that Bluetooth low
energy is quite vulnerable. You can do shy hacker attacks. You can do a lot of stuff. Uh, so,
we uh, we unloaded um, a test application that some of these providers uh, allowed you to
use. To interact with the device and to see if the device is working properly or not. Um, so
we hacked this application to make it work with Bluetooth uh, low energy. And we used
BiddleJack which is a tool that we love a lot. Using 3 micro bits connected to a USB hub. We
were able to sniff all the, the advertisement packets. And we tried to, we, we were able to
sniff uh, critical information from a payment. And you can see in the left there is the, the
application itself. Testing application. It will show you the same, the same information,
the same information that we sent to the backend. And will be deciphered at the end. And you can
see in the right, the wire shack analysis. And you can see the same information is being shown
on both sides. So we are, we, we are, uh, we are sniffing the same information that we've
been sent to uh, the backend. So the, the Bluetooth is not adding any uh, adding any
ciphering over the traffic. But, we will try to, to do the same attack against all the
digital wallets. We weren't able to it, to do it. Because, mostly because all of them use a
Bluetooth EDR which is the 3.0. And it's based on the pairing mesca- mechanism. So uh, to
see what is the, the data that is sending over Bluetooth EDR we were able to get the HCI
debug log from Android. And uh, doing, we run a lot of analysis over this traffic. And we
found out that the same data is traveling over the, the HCI. But, since a Bluetooth EDR is
adding another uh, layer of, of ciphering, you cannot get this information from just sniffing
Bluetooth uh, 3.0. And if you will, were able to do it, you'll need a really expensive tool
which we don't have. But doing just a little bit of research over these devices, uh, you'll
see that the first time you try to pair this device to your phone, you'll be uh, shown with a
numeric comparison. Numeric comparison is basically uh, a pairing method where you show
the same six digit number on the device and on the um, on the phone. And you need to
click accept on those devices. I don't know if you see what's the problem. You have, you
don't have any screen in those devices. You have no way to see or to know what are you
pairing to. So we tried to do a money to me attack. Uh, basically what we created is just a
very simple script where you, where you use a single Bluetooth adapter and basically doing a
Bluetooth analysis over the traffic. We found out that all the traffic information was sent
over Bluetooth with an SPP protocol which is basically serial over Bluetooth. It's just
transmit and send data. That's it. You need just one channel. So we emulated a channel and
we created a simple script which is trying to listen uh, based on a reg ex just to see if
there is a device that is turned on. Other thing that you need to keep in mind is that for
each transaction you need to turn on the device because it turns uh, off itself after three,
maybe five minutes. So for each transaction you need to turn it on and it accepts connection
from pretty much anyone because again, you don't have any way to pair it correctly with any
other, with any device. So uh, our script what it does is trying to start listening in the
air, it just connects as fast as it can to the device and then it starts emulating the same
device and provides the same SPP protocol. So that's the setup. It's pretty simple. You have
on one side the device turned on, uh Raspberry Pi with Python and then the device, the
mobile application will try to connect automatically to the device that we are emulating. So
this is demo. Um, this is one digital wallet. You can see right here that that's the, the
remote desktop for the, the Raspberry Pi. We try, we start the, the money in the attack. You
can see that it's already uh, saw the device, it's connected to itself and right now it's
emulating the same device. So I, I just uh, entered to the mobile application, uh, and
the digital wallet. I go to try to make a payment and right now those devices are paired but
you'll see that everything works pretty good. Right now you can see all the quick, the
drafting information between the application, the Raspberry Pi and the, the impulse
device. For now I'll try to make a payment and you can see all the, the information right
from here on the money in the attack. So, the payment mechanism doesn't allow you to know
what are you actually paying to. The device doesn't know who it's paying to and the mobile
application doesn't know. So what can we do with this? Um, with the money in the attack we
can do basically uh, create uh, max type, we can try to do a max type stealing. Uh, since
the device is connected from, from A1 you can try to do an over the air update or, or uh,
a back update which is the key that is itself. Or you can try to do a dual copy bypass which
is pretty much the same as Celiana shown but on Bluetooth level. You try to force a, a bad
payment, you try it again, you saw, save the data from the two, the, the two manipulations
and you send just one and the other it's already valid to make a second payment. But
I want to show you uh, a little big uh, a little thing of um, this is the second try that we've
done with money in the attack. This is another digital wallet and we tried just a, a small
payment and I know you, you might be able to see something quite interesting. Um, again, the
the car owner and the, the guys that run the store doesn't know that this is a guy in the
middle. So, right here you can see that everything is working properly. I used an NFC
payment and everything is working correctly. Uh, but it's just a little different, I tried the
max type. And again, this data from the max type, this card is already expired on the
wallet, but this information should be ciphered. There's no way this information is
traveling in plain text. Right? So, first another payment. And you can see right there,
this is the plain text uh, max type information from the air. So, basically you can go to any
site. You can go to any store in Argentina that you're using this uh, solution. Sit there and
start receiving critical information. You can go with this data and emulate a card with max
proof. That's pretty much it. So, uh, moving forward. Um, hardware analysis. Uh, we are not
hardware hackers, disclaimer. We're trying to be, uh, but these are the 4 devices that are
right now available in Argentina. We took them apart and we saw that they share the same
principles amongst all of them. You have the smaller ones which don't, doesn't support NFC
and the bigger one that supports NFC, basically. So, uh, what are the valuable points? I mean,
what can I get as a low level hardware hacker from this? Well, the first thing that I think is
really interesting to have is the critical information that is traveling on the devices. Um,
DMC or EMB tokens are also very data to make a payment. So, if I get this information, I could
go make payments. Uh, the freeware might be really interesting to find bugs and hack other
devices. Uh, the IP key which allow, will allow me to, uh, decipher my own data and they
may make, uh, another payment. Or maybe the UART logs will allow me to, to see a few logs.
That might be, uh, leaking important information. But you can see right here, this is, uh,
really basic. Uh, this is the connectors and things that you might find in, in these devices.
You have a Bluetooth connector, an EMB connector, we connect to a chip, a controller, um,
mag stripe which is pretty much a tape head connected to a level fire. And in the back, well,
you can see the level fire and the EMB front end. And of course the Bluetooth, um, I don't know
if I said it already. Uh, but in the bigger devices you might find, again, Bluetooth, a
microcontroller, uh, we found out that there's a flash memory. Uh, we suspect this, this is
where the firmware is stored. Uh, we have as well a tape head, a battery controller and an EFC
front end, of course, to interact with NFC. So this is something, this is a very basic
diagram on what are the, the main components that all these devices will have. So we went to
for the long-hauling fruit and after running a few analysis stuff later we found out the
device was still working, all open. So do you have any anti-tampering measures? And that's a
must. When you have a, a credit card or, or credit card reader or whatever payment system, you
need to have anti-tampering measures to avoid anyone to just hook in the data bus and start
stealing information. Why? Because you have clear text traffic between each one of the
cont- your, your components. You have the controller which provide, which provide you with a
little bit of, uh, cryptography but in the meanwhile, I mean, between the data is traveling
from the, the peripheral and the controller you have clear text traffic. So we went for the
long-hauling fruit and we tried to, to get the max-stripe information from a simple swipe,
which is pretty much like a common schemer. That's pretty much what it is. So, um, that's
the, um, that's the amplifier. It's connected to the tape head and we connected an oscilloscope
to the tape head and you can see in the right, in the left that you have a waveform which is
encoding for the credit card information from the, from the max-stripe and you can see that
the, the, the shape is very specific. So this is what we saw on the oscilloscope. Pretty much
the same shape. This data is on clear ta- text traffic. So, we got the data, we tried to
create a schemer. A schemer will try to get this data and transmit it over the air, whatever
we can. Disclaimer, this is overkill, of course. Don't, don't get angry. Uh, there's another
way to do this, I'll, I'll show you but, heh, we used, uh, BluePill which is an Arduino with a
specific chipset that allowed me to have really high rates of analog reads over the, the, the
data that is being sent between the tape head and the controller. And we were seeing all this
data on raw data over the Bluetooth which is again, overkill. And we were seeing this data
with, um, a Raspberry Pi connected to a Bombercat which is a device that amongst other
things allow you to emulate credit card information. So we created a little script for both
these things. Uh, Raspberry Pi will decode the data, will create, will create the, the
specific, uh, MaxPod data that need to be sent to the Bombercat over serial and the Bombercat
will emulate this data. So, uh, here's the demo. So, here's the test application. Here's the
open device. It's working right now as, as it is. Here's the, um, the hardware input
implant and that's the receiver. And that's another, uh, card, uh, credit card receiver.
Basically to see that the same information that we have sent are the same one that we are
emulating. So right now I'll try to make a swipe. And you'll see that all this information
right now has been sent over Bluetooth. This is all the, the data points and right now you
can see that right at the bottom that's the track 2 of the decoded data. And this data is
being sent to the Bombercat that is in the bottom. You cannot see it right now. And right now
I'm emulating the data and you can see that pretty much it's the, the same. Uh, not pretty
much. It's the same data, this track 2 that we were able to send over here. Again, this
overkill, uh, this way, easier way to do this. But this is what, uh, worked for us. And this,
uh, just to show you, uh, that the device is still working by itself. Right now you can see
that the, the hardware input, again because we are not hardware hackers, is creating a lot of
noises. Um, so when I try to make a payment, uh, of course it, it will fail but if I
disconnected the hardware input, you'll see that everything will work. Um, I just
disconnected the, the device and you can see that you're receiving the same encrypt data.
What this device is supposed to do when it's open, it should wipe out all the keys and you
shouldn't be able to cipher any data. So this is a big deal because, uh, you know if you're
paying, uh, even though the, the network traffic or the Bluetooth traffic might not be
tampered, you know if there is anything embedded in the device. Uh, so this is what the
schema implant looks like. It's quite big. Uh, it's huge. Uh, the receiver you can see on the
left and you can see the transmitter on the right. It's pretty big. But we found out that
there's another way to do it. We used a very simple 433, uh, RF transmitter. Connected
directly to the, the, the, the energy input of the, the same device. And we were able to, uh,
make a few swipes and transmit the same data over to our receiver. And you can see that's
quite small. The thing that we weren't able to decode this data correctly because there's a
lot of noises and these devices are not, uh, uh, not that good at transmitting, uh, uh,
really, uh, nice information over here. So the last thing that, uh, the last analysis, uh,
working on one of those, uh, digital wallet companies, we saw that using, you should, you
should keep in mind that it's a trust chain between the device and the backend. Because since
the same keys being generated on both ends, uh, all the data is trusted between each one of
the points. So, um, in most of digital wallets you have this, uh, fraud prevention systems
where you are trying to make a same payment over and over. And if it fails three, maybe four
times, your credit card might be blocked. So we were seeing that, that we, we, we heard, we
heard about a lot of clients complain about payments that they never had done. And we were
seeing that there was a lot of tryout payments for a bigger amount of money, um, and all
failed. And pretty much every payment was the same, the data from the payment, the credit card
was the same, but they were changing the CBV number which is a secure number embedded
inside the, the MaxStack information. So we tried to replicate this problem to see what the
fuck is, what is going on. And we found out that, uh, we, we created a MaxPoof, we didn't
have the, the bumper cut, uh, back then. And we tried the same, to do the same execution.
Just trying to change the CBV number. And we find out that the application behaved really
differently even though the credit card was blocked. The, the, the application behaved
